comments:
build N20050328

I've seen this in my own workspace as well, since I20050315.  When this happens,
it leaves zombie editors around in the list (e.g. they show up in the Ctrl+F6 list).

Could this be due to recent EditorManager changes?
It should not be trying to restore editors while closing all editors.

Also, why does unzooming trigger part restoration?  Unzooming should not change
the active part, which should already be restored.

     [java] !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2005-03-28 08:48:52.656
     [java] !MESSAGE No saved state can be found for this editor
     [java] ----- testCloseActiveFastView
     [java] testCloseActiveFastView: setUp...
     [java] testCloseActiveFastView: tearDown...
Please investigate for M7.
Or M6 <g>.
To clarify, the output above is from the console output for that build:
.../eclipse/downloads/drops/N20050328-0010/testresults/consolelogs/win32_consolelog.txt
Unzooming can trigger part restoration because there may be a view (or editor)
that was obscured by the zoomed part and it may not have been lazily activated
yet. In this situation, unzooming will cause the part to become visible for the
first time and trigger restoration. Making something visible will restore it --
it doesn't need to be the active part.
OK, makes sense.  There were other stack traces in the console log where the NPE
did not involve an unzoom.  

It looks like the editor mementos are getting blown away too early, e.g. by the
closeAllEditors call.  For close all editors, though, it would be nice if it
could avoid restoring any editors.
Got it again with testing candidate for M6.

I'm finding stale editors in the list after this occurs, suggesting this causes
leaks.
Just saw this again in I20050330-0500 (twice).
This time I wasn't zoomed, so there's no unzoom.

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2005-03-30 14:23:39.413
!MESSAGE No saved state can be found for this editor
Trying to open different flavours of editors then Ctrl+Shift+W to close all,
does not reproduce the problem.

I've released some extra debugging info to Editor.getRestoredInput() to include
the editor id and name in the message of the PartInitException.
Hopefully this will help us track this down.

Nick, did you release this into an I-build? I'm using I20050331-0010 and do not
see any additional info.
No, I did not.  It was 11:30pm, I was tired and didn't want to risk goofing the
build up.
Nick: There was already code in place to record the editor ID. From your
previous stack trace:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2005-03-30 14:23:39.303
!MESSAGE Unable to create editor ID : No saved state can be found for this
editor

The ID of the problematic editor was the empty string.
The editor dropdown gets its information from the presentation's tabs -- it will
always be in synch with what you see on the screen (and it only shows what's in
one stack).

The editor list (ctrl-shift-e) gets its information from the IWorkbenchPage
editor list. This is based on the current state of the workbench.

The editor history gets its info from the activation list. It appears that a
bogus editor ended up in the activation list.
Now it's:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2005-04-01 13:16:23.651
!MESSAGE Unable to create editor ID : No saved state can be found for editor id=
name=<null>
!STACK 1
org.eclipse.ui.PartInitException: No saved state can be found for editor id=
name=<null>
Spent some time investigating. It appears that this is what is happening: 

When we close the active editor, we first close it and then activate a second
editor. This means that for a short time a disposed editor reference is the
active editor. The solution is to always activate something else (or deactivate
everything) before closing the active editor -- we should never dispose an
editor while it is active.

This regression showed up in the part creation refactoring. Previously, the
pointer to the active editor would have been updated before the editor was fully
initialized. This was changed to update the active editor pointer after the new
editor was fully materialized, but it means when closing editors we end up
pointing to the old disposed editor rather than the new uninitialized editor
(which is just as bad).

By updating activation before closing anything, this problem should happily
disappear. If we also add this to the API contract ("parts are always
deactivated and hidden before closing"), then it will give clients some nice
invariants to code against, and they can remove the common special-case code in
IPartListener/IPartListener2 implementations that needs to check if the part
being closed is the active view/editor.
Sounds good.  Let's put this fix in for early M7.
